misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to sort parallel arrays by score, you must swap both the score elements and the corresponding name elements whenever two scores are out of order, and then the top student will be at the last index after an ascending sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap detected. This matches Java’s execution model: the nested loops perform a bubble-sort-like pass, and swapping both arrays in tandem preserves the name↔score association.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None for the stated requirements; the program will print the correct top student after sorting ascending by score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Inefficient Sorting Implementation (Bubble Sort without Early Termination)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that running a nested loop structure with n iterations of the outer loop and n-1 iterations of the inner loop will correctly sort an array. The student implemented bubble sort but included an unnecessary outer loop that iterates n times, when bubble sort only needs at most n passes and can terminate early once no swaps occur in a complete pass.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has implemented a working bubble sort algorithm but with poor efficiency. While the code will produce correct output for this problem, it demonstrates a misunderstanding of sorting algorithm optimization. Specifically, the outer loop running exactly n times is wasteful—bubble sort only requires n-1 passes in the worst case, and can terminate as soon as a complete pass occurs with no swaps (indicating the array is sorted). This suggests the student may not fully understand the termination conditions for bubble sort or the concept of early exit optimization.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code produces correct output but uses O(n²) iterations unconditionally rather than terminating early when the array is already sorted. For large datasets or nearly-sorted data, this represents a significant performance penalty.

evidence.code_snippet: for(int i=0;i<n;i++) // outer loop runs n times unconditionally, even if array is sorted after fewer passes

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when sorting one array (scores), they must manually swap corresponding elements in the parallel array (names) whenever a swap occurs in the primary array. The student correctly understands that both arrays must be kept in sync during sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This is actually NOT a misconception—the student correctly implements the parallel array swap logic. When z[j] and z[j+1] are swapped, the corresponding y[j] and y[j+1] are also swapped to maintain the correspondence between names and scores. This demonstrates proper understanding of parallel arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error—the parallel array swaps are implemented correctly.
